title: Stakeholder Adoption and Usage
statement: These requirements have since been used by a variety of stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and several country governments, including that of Bangladesh.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence of requirement adoption by OpenHIE is documented.
Evidence of requirement adoption by openIMIS is documented.
Evidence of requirement adoption by the government of Bangladesh is documented.

metadata.raw_input: These requirements have since been used by a variety of stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and several country governments, including that of Bangladesh.

title: Update National Health Insurance System Requirements Guide
statement: A 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' must be updated, based on the results of the Determining workshop, to supersede the 2012 version of the document.
acceptance_criteria: A new version of the 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' is published.
The new guide incorporates all relevant outputs from the 'Determining workshop'.
The new guide is formally approved and designated as the replacement for the 2012 document.

metadata.raw_input: A Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems This document, , is the result of that Determining workshop and the next step toward updating the content of the 2012 document.

title: Update National Health Insurance Information Systems Guide
statement: The 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' must be updated to incorporate the results of the 'Determining workshop', serving as the official replacement for the 2012 version of the document.
acceptance_criteria: A new version of the 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' is drafted and approved.
The new guide explicitly incorporates the findings and decisions from the 'Determining workshop'.
The updated document is officially published and communicated as the replacement for the 2012 version.

metadata.raw_input: A Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems This document, , is the result of that Determining workshop and the next step toward updating the content of the 2012 document.

title: Community Contribution for Living Resource
statement: This document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource.
acceptance_criteria: A formal process for community contribution is defined and documented.
A platform or channel for submitting contributions is established.
A review and approval workflow for submitted contributions is in place.
The requirements document is updated periodically based on community feedback.

metadata.raw_input: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource.

title: National Health Insurance System Context
statement: The system must be designed in the context of a national health insurance system, which operationalizes health financing transactions for paying for and delivering health services as part of a country's progress toward Universal Health Coverage for its citizens.
acceptance_criteria: The system's purpose and design documentation must align with the principles of supporting a national health insurance framework.
Stakeholder documentation confirms the system's role in contributing to Universal Health Coverage goals.

metadata.raw_input: A guide to common requirements for nAtionAl heAlth insurAnce informAtion systems PAge 5 Introduction National health insurance systems are becoming more common as countries move to operationalize health financing transactions of paying for and delivering health services as part of their progress toward Universal Health Coverage for their citizens.

title: Living Document Contribution and Update Process
statement: A process shall be established for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure the requirements document continues to have value as a living resource.
acceptance_criteria: A documented process for submitting, reviewing, and incorporating updates from the community is established.
A designated channel (e.g., a portal, a repository, a contact person) for community contributions is created and communicated.
The requirements document is reviewed and updated on a defined periodic basis (e.g., annually).

metadata.raw_input: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource. A guide to common requirements for nAtionAl heAlth insurAnce informAtion systems PAge 5 Introduction National health insurance systems are becoming more common as countries move to operationalize health financing transactions of paying for and delivering health services as part of their progress toward Universal Health Coverage for their citizens.

title: National Scale Health Scheme Support
statement: The health insurance or health purchaser information system must be designed and implemented to support schemes operating at a national scale, ensuring compliance, reliability, and performance under the increased importance and load of such implementations.
acceptance_criteria: The system architecture must be documented and validated to be scalable for a national-level deployment.
The system must demonstrate compliance with all relevant national healthcare and data privacy regulations for the target country.
Performance and stress testing results must prove the system can handle projected peak user and transaction loads for a national scheme.

metadata.raw_input: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale.

title: Health Insurance Information System Efficacy
statement: Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.
regulation: HIPAA - Security Rule - 45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C
acceptance_criteria: The system must process 95% of standard electronic claims for reimbursement within 14 business days.
The system must demonstrate a 10% reduction in cost-per-claim-processed compared to the previous system within the first year of operation.
The system must include reporting dashboards that identify bottlenecks in the claims processing workflow, such as average time spent in each status.
The system must automatically flag claims that match predefined fraud-detection rules with a 98% accuracy rate on a test dataset.
The system must be able to generate audit reports to verify that claims are adjudicated based on policy rules without statistical bias related to patient demographics.

metadata.raw_input: Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.

title: Health Insurance Information System Core Capabilities
statement: The health insurance information system must be designed to support national-scale schemes by enabling timely reimbursements, decreasing transaction costs, identifying system efficiencies, preventing fraud, and ensuring equitable coverage and treatment.
acceptance_criteria: The system must process and issue decisions on 95% of standard electronic claims within 15 business days.
The system must provide analytics tools to identify and report on transaction cost metrics, demonstrating a measurable reduction over a 12-month period.
The system must include a fraud detection module that automatically flags at least 90% of known fraudulent pattern types.
The system must be capable of generating reports to audit coverage and treatment distribution across different demographic groups to ensure equity.
System uptime must be 99.9% to ensure continuous access for claims processing and reimbursement.

metadata.raw_input: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale. Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.

title: Health Insurance Data Integration
statement: The system shall be capable of ingesting, processing, and integrating health insurance data to complement other existing health system data sources, such as clinical records or lab results.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C (Security Rule)
acceptance_criteria: The system provides a mechanism to connect to and ingest data from a specified health insurance data source.
Ingested health insurance data is correctly parsed and stored in a structured format.
The system can successfully link health insurance records to the corresponding patient records within the main health system.
Authorized users can query and view the combined dataset of health system data and complementary insurance data.
All actions involving access and integration of health insurance data are logged in an audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: Many countries are also finding value in health insurance data to complement other types of health system data.

title: Health Insurance Data Integration
statement: The system shall support the integration of health insurance data to complement other types of health system data for analytical purposes.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C (Security Rule)
HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E (Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: The system can establish a secure connection to a specified health insurance data source.
Health insurance data can be ingested and linked to corresponding patient records from other health system data sources (e.g., EMR).
A user with appropriate permissions can generate a report that combines data points from the health insurance source and another health system data source.

metadata.raw_input: Many countries are also finding value in health insurance data to complement other types of health system data.

title: Value of Functional Requirements
statement: Functional requirements are an invaluable tool for policymakers and systems engineering, and technical experts alike.

metadata.raw_input: Functional requirements are an invaluable tool for policymakers and systems engineering, and technical experts alike.

title: Export National Healthcare Priorities
statement: The system shall provide a function for authorized experts to access and export national healthcare priorities in a structured, machine-readable format (e.g., JSON, XML) suitable for integration with other software components.
acceptance_criteria: GIVEN an authorized expert is logged into the system, WHEN they navigate to the national priorities feature, THEN the system must display the current priorities.
GIVEN the national priorities are displayed, WHEN the expert selects the export option, THEN the system must generate a file.
GIVEN a file has been generated, THEN the file must be in a valid, machine-readable format (e.g., JSON or XML).
GIVEN the exported file, THEN its content and structure must conform to the predefined data schema for national priorities.

metadata.raw_input: Technical defines a function of a system experts gain clarity on the national priorities in a format that is transferable to software or its component, where a design and implementation.

title: Understandable Requirement Format
statement: The requirement specification format must be understandable to both non-technical stakeholders (e.g., health insurance experts) and technical stakeholders (e.g., software engineers). This format should serve as a common platform for specifying system behavior, prioritizing features, negotiating compromises, and informing system design.
acceptance_criteria: A sample requirement can be reviewed and correctly interpreted by a representative from the business/health insurance team.
The same sample requirement can be reviewed and correctly interpreted by a representative from the software engineering team.
Feedback from both business and engineering teams during review sessions indicates a shared understanding of specified behaviors.

metadata.raw_input: These requirements provide a format that is understandable function is described as a to both health insurance experts and software engineers, providing a platform for specification of behavior prioritization, compromise, and system design.

title: Understandable and Transferable Requirement Specification
statement: System requirements must be defined in a structured format that is understandable to both domain experts (e.g., health insurance experts) and technical experts (e.g., software engineers). This format must clearly specify system behavior and be directly transferable for software design and implementation, serving as a basis for prioritization, compromise, and system design.
acceptance_criteria: A standardized requirement template is created and approved by both domain and technical stakeholders.
A sample functional requirement, written using the template, is reviewed and confirmed to be clear and unambiguous by representatives from both health insurance and software engineering teams.
The requirement format is suitable for direct use in system design and implementation planning.

metadata.raw_input: Technical defines a function of a system experts gain clarity on the national priorities in a format that is transferable to software or its component, where a design and implementation. These requirements provide a format that is understandable function is described as a to both health insurance experts and software engineers, providing a platform for specification of behavior prioritization, compromise, and system design.

title: Jurisdictional and Organizational Specificity
statement: The system must be configurable to meet specific compliance, functional, and data handling requirements as defined by the country or organization in which it is deployed.
acceptance_criteria: System configuration must provide mechanisms to enable or disable features based on jurisdictional or organizational policies.
System must demonstrate the ability to enforce a sample country-specific data residency rule (e.g., storing EU patient data only within EU data centers).
System must demonstrate the ability to enforce a sample organization-specific workflow requirement.
Audit trails must log the enforcement of these specific rules and any configuration changes related to them.

metadata.raw_input: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs.

title: Leverage Common Requirements for Development
statement: A set of globally defined common requirements shall be used as a starting point for development to ensure adherence to best practices and to optimize time and resources.
acceptance_criteria: A documented set of common requirements is established and maintained.
Evidence demonstrates that development projects reference and utilize the common requirements set as a baseline.
Project documentation shows traceability from specific features back to the common requirements where applicable.

metadata.raw_input: The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.

title: Leverage Global Requirements Baseline
statement: The development process shall leverage a set of globally defined common requirements as an advanced starting point to review best practices, saving time and resources. Country- or organization-specific requirements will be defined to address specific needs, building upon this common baseline.
acceptance_criteria: A documented set of globally defined common requirements is established and used as the project's baseline.
Evidence exists of a formal review of the baseline requirements at the project's outset.
Country- or organization-specific requirements are documented, with clear traceability to the common baseline they extend or modify.

metadata.raw_input: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs. The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.

title: Creating Common Requirements
statement: Creating common requirements. While common requirements are a useful building block, creating them can be a challenge.
acceptance_criteria: A standardized template for defining common requirements must be available.
The system must provide a mechanism to reuse or link common requirements across different system components.
A central repository for storing, viewing, and managing common requirements must be established.

metadata.raw_input: CreAting common requirements While common requirements are a useful building block, creating them can be a challenge.

title: Adaptability to Diverse Health Coverage Schemes
statement: The system shall be designed to accommodate and support a variety of country-specific health coverage schemes, which differ in their design, coverage rules, and maturity levels.
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide a configuration interface for administrators to define and manage rules for different health coverage schemes without requiring code changes.
The system must correctly apply the configured coverage rules (e.g., co-pay, deductible, covered services) for at least three distinct, simulated country schemes.
Patient eligibility and coverage details must be accurately processed and displayed based on the rules of their specific, configured scheme.

metadata.raw_input: Country health coverage schemes range in design, coverage, and maturity—all of which require different types of requirements to function appropriately.

title: Adaptability to Country-Specific Health Schemes
statement: The system must be designed to accommodate and adapt to the diverse designs, coverage levels, and maturity of different country-specific health coverage schemes. This includes supporting varying types of requirements needed for each scheme to function appropriately.
acceptance_criteria: The system can be configured to support at least three distinct country health coverage schemes (e.g., US-based PPO, UK's NHS, German statutory health insurance) without requiring code changes.
Configuration for a new country scheme can be performed by an Admin user through a dedicated interface.
Rules for coverage, billing, and data handling specific to a configured country scheme are correctly applied and can be verified through end-to-end testing scenarios for that country.

metadata.raw_input: CreAting common requirements While common requirements are a useful building block, creating them can be a challenge. Country health coverage schemes range in design, coverage, and maturity—all of which require different types of requirements to function appropriately.

title: CRDM Framework Applicability
statement: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more.
acceptance_criteria: The project's requirements are developed and documented using the CRDM framework.
The applicability of the CRDM model to the project's specific domain (e.g., health insurance, maternal health) is documented and approved.
A review confirms that the system's requirements align with the principles and structure of CRDM.

metadata.raw_input: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more.

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.
acceptance_criteria: All user-facing text, labels, and messages are written at or below an 8th-grade reading level, as measured by a standard readability index (e.g., Flesch-Kincaid).
Usability testing with a panel of representative users (clinicians, patients) confirms that system terminology is clear and understandable with a success rate of >95% on comprehension tasks.
A glossary of terms used in the system is reviewed and approved by a panel of subject matter experts and target users.

metadata.raw_input: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: A key aspect of the system's effectiveness is the use of non-technical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts. All user-facing text, including labels, messages, and documentation, must be clear, concise, and free of technical jargon.
acceptance_criteria: All user-facing text is written at an 8th-grade reading level or below.
User acceptance testing with a panel of representative users confirms that system terminology is clear and understandable with a success rate of over 95%.
A glossary of terms is created, reviewed, and approved by subject matter experts.
No technical acronyms are used in the user interface without a readily available, on-screen definition (e.g., tooltip).

metadata.raw_input: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more. A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.

title: Beneficiary Management Capability
statement: The system must provide core beneficiary management capabilities, applicable to all healthcare schemes, regardless of whether a specific scheme requires formal beneficiary enrollment.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C (Security Rule)
HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E (Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: Given an authorized user, when they access the beneficiary management module, they can create a new beneficiary record.
Given an authorized user, when they search for a beneficiary by a unique identifier (e.g., name, ID), the system returns the correct beneficiary record.
Given an authorized user, when they select a beneficiary record, they can view and update the beneficiary's information.
The system provides a mechanism to manage beneficiaries for schemes that do not have a formal enrollment process.
The system provides a mechanism to manage beneficiaries for schemes that do have a formal enrollment process.

metadata.raw_input: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.

title: Beneficiary Management
statement: The system must support beneficiary management functions, such as creating, viewing, and updating beneficiary records, for all schemes, regardless of whether a specific scheme requires formal beneficiary enrollment.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C (Security Rule)
HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E (Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: Given an authorized user is logged in, when they navigate to the beneficiary management section, then they should be able to create a new beneficiary record.
Given an authorized user is logged in, when they search for an existing beneficiary, then the system should display the correct beneficiary's details.
Given an authorized user is viewing a beneficiary's record, when they edit and save changes, then the record must be updated with the new information.
Given an authorized user is viewing a beneficiary's record, when they perform the 'archive' or 'deactivate' action, then the beneficiary's status must be updated to inactive.
Given a user without administrative privileges is logged in, when they attempt to access beneficiary creation or modification functions, then the system must deny access.

metadata.raw_input: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.

title: Interoperability Standards Compliance
statement: The system shall utilize HL7 FHIR and other relevant global standards for data exchange to ensure interoperability and alignment of business processes across different digital health systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system's data exchange APIs must be implemented using the HL7 FHIR standard.
Data payloads for key resources (e.g., Patient, Observation, MedicationRequest) must validate against the corresponding FHIR profiles.
Successful data exchange (read/write) with a reference FHIR-compliant system must be demonstrated.
All data exchanged over the network must be encrypted using industry-standard protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2+).

metadata.raw_input: HL7 FHIR HL7 FHIR, and other global standards for data exchange, are helpful frameworks for aligning business processes across digital health systems.

title: Support for Global Data Exchange Standards
statement: The system shall leverage HL7 FHIR and other global standards for data exchange to ensure interoperability and the alignment of business processes across different digital health systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system's data exchange APIs must be compliant with the HL7 FHIR standard, verified through successful validation against a public FHIR validator.
The system must demonstrate successful and secure data exchange (e.g., retrieving a patient record, submitting an observation) with at least one other FHIR-compliant third-party system.
System architecture documentation must explicitly map business processes for data exchange to the corresponding HL7 FHIR resources and workflows.

metadata.raw_input: HL7 FHIR HL7 FHIR, and other global standards for data exchange, are helpful frameworks for aligning business processes across digital health systems.

title: Business Process Task Sets
statement: The system must support the definition and management of task sets, which represent the required activities or steps to be carried out within a business process.
acceptance_criteria: An administrator can create a new business process definition.
Within a business process definition, an administrator can define a set of one or more tasks.
The system allows for the ordering and configuration of steps within the task set.
The defined task set is saved and associated with its parent business process.
An administrator can view, edit, and delete an existing task set.

metadata.raw_input: • Task set(s): The set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.

title: Task Set Definition
statement: The system shall support the creation and management of Task Sets, which are defined as the set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.
regulation: HIPAA 164.308(a)(1)(ii)(A) - Implementation of policies and procedures
acceptance_criteria: An administrator can define a new Task Set.
A Task Set must contain one or more ordered steps or activities.
The system allows for a Task Set to be associated with a business process.
Users can view the steps of a Task Set relevant to their role and assigned work.

metadata.raw_input: • Task set(s): The set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.

title: Scheme Comparison and Selection
statement: The system shall provide a clear outline of the differences between available healthcare schemes, enabling administrative users to understand the breadth of options and select processes most relevant to their country's or organization's needs.
acceptance_criteria: Given an administrative user is logged in, when they navigate to the scheme configuration area, then the system must display a comparison of all available schemes.
The comparison view must clearly detail the key differences, features, and implications of each scheme in a side-by-side or tabular format.
The user must be able to select a scheme or a combination of processes to apply to their instance.
Upon selection and confirmation, the system must save the chosen configuration and reflect it in the system's behavior.

metadata.raw_input: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.

title: Scheme Process Options Display
statement: The system shall outline the differences between available processes, enabling users to understand the breadth of options and select the most relevant ones for their specific scheme.
acceptance_criteria: Given an administrator is on the scheme configuration page,
When the administrator views the process options,
Then the system must display a clear comparison of all available processes.
And the comparison must detail the key differences, benefits, and implications of each option.
And the administrator must be able to select and save a process configuration for their scheme.

metadata.raw_input: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.

title: Business Process Visualization
statement: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.
acceptance_criteria: Given a defined business process, the system must render a graphical representation (e.g., a flowchart or BPMN diagram).
The graphical representation must clearly label all actors/roles involved in the process.
The diagram must depict the flow of information between actors, including the type of data exchanged.
The sequence of tasks, decision points, and process start/end points must be visually clear.
A user with appropriate permissions can access and view the process visualization.

metadata.raw_input: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.

title: Beneficiary Insurer Identification Verification
statement: The system must support a process for an authorized user to capture and verify a beneficiary's insurer identification information. The process must ensure the information is accurate by requiring the beneficiary to present physical or digital proof of their insurer identification.
regulation: HIPAA Privacy Rule (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E)
HIPAA Security Rule (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C)
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide an interface for an authorized user to input or update a beneficiary's insurer identification information.
The system must enforce the entry of mandatory fields such as Member ID, Group ID, and Insurer Name.
The user must be able to confirm within the system that the entered information has been visually verified against the beneficiary's proof of identification (e.g., via a checkbox 'ID Verified').
An audit trail must be generated upon the successful update of the beneficiary's insurance information, logging the user, timestamp, and data changed.
The process is considered complete when the verified insurance information is successfully saved to the beneficiary's record.

metadata.raw_input: Present identification process and/or process will end with beneficiary to ensure it is information as required by the Beneficiary presents proof of accurate insurer identification 5.

title: Beneficiary Insurer Identification Verification
statement: The system must facilitate a process where a beneficiary presents proof of their insurer identification, and an authorized user verifies and records this information to ensure its accuracy within the beneficiary's record.

metadata.raw_input: Present identification process and/or process will end with beneficiary to ensure it is information as required by the Beneficiary presents proof of accurate insurer identification 5.

title: Beneficiary Credential and Eligibility Verification
statement: The system must allow an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, biometrics) and supporting documents to verify their validity and ensure all required data fields are complete. The system must also handle cases where a beneficiary qualifies for multiple benefit plans.
regulation: HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C - Security Rule)
HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E - Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: An authorized Insurer user can access the beneficiary's submitted identification information and documents.
The system must display all required fields for beneficiary identification (e.g., name, address, biometrics).
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to mark the data and documents as 'valid' or 'invalid'.
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to confirm that all required fields are complete.
If a beneficiary qualifies for multiple plans based on the verified data, the system must present these plans to the Insurer for selection or further processing.

metadata.raw_input: beneficiary credentials Insurer reviews identification information (i.e., name, address, Insurer reviews the captured In the even that there are several and other appropriate qualifying biometrics…) data to ensure that all of the benefits plans for which the documents for validity appropriate fields are complete beneficiary qualifies, then the 6.

title: Beneficiary Credential and Eligibility Verification
statement: The system shall allow an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, qualifying biometrics) and supporting documents for validity. The review must ensure that all required data fields are complete to determine eligibility for benefits plans. In the event a beneficiary qualifies for multiple plans, the system must present these options appropriately.
acceptance_criteria: An authorized Insurer user can access the beneficiary's submitted identification information and documents.
The system must display all required fields for beneficiary identification and eligibility determination.
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to approve or reject the submitted information and documents based on validity and completeness.
The system must visually flag any incomplete or missing required fields.
If a beneficiary is determined to be eligible for more than one benefits plan, the system must list all applicable plans for the Insurer to review.

metadata.raw_input: beneficiary credentials Insurer reviews identification information (i.e., name, address, Insurer reviews the captured In the even that there are several and other appropriate qualifying biometrics…) data to ensure that all of the benefits plans for which the documents for validity appropriate fields are complete beneficiary qualifies, then the 6.

title: Requirement Statement Formatting
statement: All system requirements must be documented as clear, complete, and unambiguous statements. Each statement must begin with the phrase 'The system must...' to ensure consistency and testability.
acceptance_criteria: All requirement statements in the specification document are reviewed for clarity and consistency.
A quality audit confirms that all requirements are written in the specified declarative format ('The system must...').
Each requirement is atomic and testable.

metadata.raw_input: statements usually begin with “The system must .

title: Requirement Statement Formatting Standard
statement: To ensure clarity, consistency, and testability, all requirement statements must be written in a standard format, beginning with the phrase 'The system must...'.
acceptance_criteria: A manual or automated review of the Requirements Specification Document (RSD) confirms that all individual requirement statements start with the phrase 'The system must...'.
The project's documentation style guide is updated to include this formatting rule.
During requirement review meetings, any non-compliant statements are flagged for correction.

metadata.raw_input: statements usually begin with “The system must .

title: Technology-Agnostic Requirement Formulation
statement: All requirements must be defined by what the system shall accomplish, not how it is accomplished. Statements must be technology-agnostic, avoiding any reference to specific implementation details, platforms, or proprietary software/hardware components unless explicitly defined as a constraint.
acceptance_criteria: A review of any requirement statement confirms it does not mention specific programming languages, databases, hardware models, or commercial software products.
Each requirement focuses on the 'what' (the business or user need) rather than the 'how' (the technical implementation).
Requirement statements are understandable to non-technical stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.

title: Technology-Agnostic Requirement Formulation
statement: All system requirements shall be written to describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to implementation technology, platforms, or vendors. Each requirement must be a complete, verifiable statement.

metadata.raw_input: .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.

title: Common System Requirement Example
statement: Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should .

metadata.raw_input: Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should .

title: Process Activity Management
statement: The system must provide a mechanism for authorized users to define, manage, and execute process activities based on common system requirements.
acceptance_criteria: Given an authenticated administrator, when they navigate to the process management section, then the system displays an interface to create and manage process activities.
Given the process activity creation interface, when the administrator defines the steps and rules for a new activity and saves it, then the system confirms the creation and lists the new activity.
Given a defined process activity, when a trigger event occurs, then the system must execute the corresponding process activity as defined.

metadata.raw_input: Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should .

title: Incorporate Country-Specific Requirements
statement: In turn, country-specific requirements are used to update and expand the global set of requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A documented process exists for identifying and reviewing country-specific requirements.
When a new or updated country-specific requirement is approved, the global requirements set is reviewed for necessary updates or expansions.
Changes to the global requirements set are traceable to the source country-specific requirement.
An audit log captures all modifications to the global requirements set, including the change, the author, and the timestamp.

metadata.raw_input: In turn, country-specific requirements are used to update and expand the global set of requirements.

title: Requirement Contextualization and Policy Alignment
statement: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.
acceptance_criteria: A documented list of applicable national policies and scheme design constraints is created and approved.
A process for reviewing and selecting requirements based on the identified context is defined and followed.
The final set of project requirements demonstrates clear traceability to the relevant policies and design constraints.

metadata.raw_input: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.

title: Contextual Requirement Analysis
statement: A review of common requirements must be conducted to identify and document the specific requirements that are relevant for the system's context, considering applicable national policies and the overall scheme design.
acceptance_criteria: A document is produced that lists all applicable national policies and scheme design constraints.
A set of specific, derived system requirements is created based on the review.
A traceability matrix is established linking each derived requirement to its source policy or design constraint.

metadata.raw_input: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.

title: Define Functional Scope
statement: The system or associated processes must allow the project team to define and document the functional scope of the application.
acceptance_criteria: A process or tool is established for documenting the functional scope.
Authorized team members can create, view, and update the documented functional scope.
The documented scope is version-controlled and accessible to all relevant stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: First, it will allow the team to define what they want to do (i.e., the functional scope).

title: Secure Team Question & Answer
statement: The system shall provide a secure communication feature for authorized team members to ask and answer essential questions related to patient care, treatment plans, or clinical data within a specific patient's context.
regulation: HIPAA Security Rule (45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C)
HIPAA Privacy Rule (45 CFR Part 164 Subpart E)
acceptance_criteria: An authorized user can initiate a new question thread associated with a specific patient.
Only authorized members of the patient's care team can view or respond to the questions.
All communications must be encrypted in transit (e.g., TLS 1.2+) and at rest (e.g., AES-256).
An immutable audit trail is created for every message sent and viewed, logging the user, timestamp, and patient ID.
The system must prevent unauthorized access to conversations, even by system administrators, without a break-glass procedure.
Users receive notifications for new questions or replies.

metadata.raw_input: It will also allow the team to ask essential questions.

title: Functional Scope Definition Process
statement: The system or process shall allow the development team to define the functional scope. It must also provide a mechanism for the team to ask and track essential questions to clarify requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A formal functional scope document (e.g., Software Requirements Specification) is created and version controlled.
The scope document clearly outlines in-scope and out-of-scope functionalities.
The functional scope is reviewed and approved by key stakeholders.
A process for asking, tracking, and resolving questions regarding the scope is established and utilized.

metadata.raw_input: First, it will allow the team to define what they want to do (i.e., the functional scope). It will also allow the team to ask essential questions.

title: Country-Specific Regulatory Compliance
statement: The system must identify, document, and comply with all relevant national and scheme-specific rules and regulations applicable to the target country context.
regulation: To be determined based on country context
Example types: HIPAA, GDPR, FDA, National Health Acts
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive list of all applicable national and scheme-specific rules for the target country is documented.
A compliance matrix is created, mapping each identified rule to the system features that address it.
System configurations are updated to enforce the identified country-specific rules.
An audit trail is in place to demonstrate adherence to these rules.
A formal compliance review report confirms that the system meets the identified national and scheme rules.

metadata.raw_input: For example: • What are the requirements that will be relevant for our country context given our national and scheme rules?

title: Provider and Payer System Requirements Definition
statement: The system development process must include the definition, documentation, and analysis of all functional, technical, and compliance requirements for both provider-side and payer-side interactions and modules.
acceptance_criteria: A formal requirements specification document for provider-side features is created and approved by stakeholders.
A formal requirements specification document for payer-side features is created and approved by stakeholders.
All defined requirements are mapped to relevant regulatory controls (e.g., HIPAA).
Requirements for data exchange formats (e.g., X12 EDI) between providers and payers are explicitly defined.

metadata.raw_input: • What requirements must be developed on the provider and payer sides?

title: Analysis of Country-Specific Requirements
statement: Analyze and define the specific requirements relevant to the target country's national and scheme rules. This analysis must identify the necessary requirements to be developed for both provider and payer systems.
regulation: Country-specific national and scheme regulations (To be determined)
acceptance_criteria: A documented report is produced detailing all relevant national and scheme rules for the target country.
A list of specific, actionable requirements for the provider-side of the system is created based on the analysis.
A list of specific, actionable requirements for the payer-side of the system is created based on the analysis.
The report and derived requirements are reviewed and approved by legal and product stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: For example: • What are the requirements that will be relevant for our country context given our national and scheme rules? • What requirements must be developed on the provider and payer sides?

title: Hospital Information System (HIS) Integration
statement: The solution must integrate with existing hospital information systems (HIS). If native integration is not supported, an interface must be designed and built to facilitate secure data exchange.
acceptance_criteria: The solution successfully establishes a connection with the target HIS using standard protocols (e.g., HL7, FHIR).
Data can be successfully queried from and sent to the HIS without corruption or data loss.
All data exchanged between the solution and the HIS is encrypted in transit using TLS 1.2 or higher.
The integration includes robust error handling for connection failures and data validation issues.
System performance is not degraded beyond acceptable limits during data exchange operations.

metadata.raw_input: • Will the solution integrate with existing hospital information systems, or will it need to have interface design built into it?

title: Requirement Prioritization
statement: The project must establish a clear method to differentiate between essential (must-have) requirements and non-essential (nice-to-have) requirements to guide development, testing, and release planning.
acceptance_criteria: A documented prioritization framework (e.g., MoSCoW) is defined and approved.
Each requirement in the product backlog is assigned a priority level.
Priority levels are used to inform sprint planning and release roadmaps.

metadata.raw_input: • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: System Integration and Requirement Prioritization
statement: The solution's integration strategy with existing Hospital Information Systems (HIS) must be defined, specifying whether it will use existing interfaces or require new interface development. Additionally, all project requirements must be formally prioritized to distinguish between essential (must-have) and non-essential (nice-to-have) features.
acceptance_criteria: A formal integration plan is documented, detailing the approach for interfacing with specified Hospital Information Systems (e.g., EHR, LIS, RIS).
The integration plan specifies whether existing APIs/interfaces will be used or if new interface development is required.
A complete requirements backlog is established, with each requirement assigned a priority level (e.g., Must-Have, Should-Have, Could-Have).
The prioritized requirements list is reviewed and approved by key stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: • Will the solution integrate with existing hospital information systems, or will it need to have interface design built into it? • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: Evaluate Solution Alternatives
statement: A formal process must be established for managers to evaluate multiple solution alternatives and select the system that best aligns with the complex and diverse needs of the organization.
regulation: HIPAA - Security Rule - 45 CFR § 164.308(a)(1)(ii)(A) Risk Analysis
HIPAA - Security Rule - 45 CFR § 164.306 Security Standards: General Rules
GDPR - Article 25: Data protection by design and by default
FDA - 21 CFR Part 820: Quality System Regulation
acceptance_criteria: A documented evaluation process for technology solutions is created and approved.
A comparison report is produced, evaluating at least two potential solutions against a predefined set of organizational, functional, and compliance requirements.
The final selection is formally documented, with a justification explaining how the chosen system meets the key requirements better than the alternatives.

metadata.raw_input: EvAluAte solutions Sometimes managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.

title: Solution Selection and Evaluation
statement: The system must provide capabilities for managers to evaluate multiple solution alternatives and choose the system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164 Subpart C (Security Rule)
GDPR - Article 25 (Data protection by design and by default)
acceptance_criteria: The system must allow for the definition of custom evaluation criteria based on organizational needs (e.g., functionality, cost, security, compliance).
The system must provide a side-by-side comparison view of multiple solution alternatives against the defined criteria.
The system must be able to generate a summary report of the evaluation, highlighting the best-matched solution based on a configurable scoring system.
The system must allow for attaching and reviewing supporting documents (e.g., vendor proposals, compliance certificates) for each alternative.

metadata.raw_input: EvAluAte solutions Sometimes managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.

title: Software Package Trade-off Analysis
statement: The software selection process must acknowledge that different software packages will have varying levels of strength across the full set of functional and non-functional requirements. A risk-based approach must be used to evaluate and accept trade-offs.
regulation: ISO 14971 - Application of risk management to medical devices
acceptance_criteria: A documented trade-off analysis or scoring matrix is produced for all shortlisted software packages.
The analysis must explicitly identify areas where a selected package is weaker and provide a documented risk assessment for those weaknesses.
A mitigation plan for identified weaknesses and risks is documented and approved.
The final selection decision, including the risk acceptance, is formally signed off by designated stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: Not every software package will be equally strong across all requirements.

title: Software Evaluation Trade-off Principle
statement: The software selection and procurement process must acknowledge that different software packages will exhibit varying levels of strength across functional, security, and performance requirements. A documented, risk-based approach must be used to evaluate and accept trade-offs, ensuring that all critical and regulatory requirements are met while documenting any accepted deficiencies in non-critical areas.
acceptance_criteria: A documented software evaluation process exists that incorporates a risk assessment methodology.
Evaluation reports for candidate software explicitly compare strengths and weaknesses against a predefined requirements matrix.
A formal record of decision is created for any selected software, justifying the choice and documenting any accepted risks or deviations from non-critical requirements.

metadata.raw_input: Not every software package will be equally strong across all requirements.

title: Requirements-Driven Development Process
statement: Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business development processes and requirements.
regulation: GDPR (Article 25, Data protection by design and by default)
acceptance_criteria: A documented Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) process exists and is accessible to the development team.
For any implemented feature, there is clear traceability from the code back to a specific, approved business requirement document.
Design documents (e.g., Software Design Specification) explicitly reference the business requirements they satisfy.
Evidence of peer or code reviews demonstrates that implemented functionality was verified against the corresponding requirements.

metadata.raw_input: Guide softwAre Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business develoPment processes and requirements.

title: Implementation Flexibility for Requirements
statement: Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.
acceptance_criteria: Functional requirements are defined in terms of inputs, outputs, and outcomes, not specific implementation details.
Code reviews confirm that developers have the flexibility to choose optimal technical solutions that meet the requirement's intent.
Design documents clearly link the proposed technical solution to the requirement's objective, allowing for alternative implementations.

metadata.raw_input: Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.

title: Developer Implementation Flexibility
statement: Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business development processes and requirements. Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.
acceptance_criteria: Traceability matrix demonstrates linkage from business requirements to software design specifications.
Design documents and test cases explicitly define and verify the required inputs, outputs, and outcomes for a given function.
Code reviews confirm that the implementation correctly produces the outcomes defined in the design specifications, regardless of the specific technical solution used.

metadata.raw_input: Guide softwAre Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business develoPment processes and requirements. Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.

title: Common Requirements Baseline for Adaptability
statement: The software design shall be based on a common requirements document that serves as a starting point, allowing for further customization to meet specific country or system needs, ensuring fulfillment of requirements across various scheme designs and structures.
acceptance_criteria: A common, version-controlled requirements document exists and is used as the baseline for all development.
The software architecture demonstrates clear points of extension or configuration for country-specific rules (e.g., via configuration files, plug-in architecture).
A process for evaluating and incorporating country-specific requirements into a custom deployment is documented and followed.
Evidence of customization for at least two different regulatory schemes (e.g., US/HIPAA and EU/GDPR) can be demonstrated.

metadata.raw_input: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.

title: Common Requirements Baseline for Customization
statement: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.
acceptance_criteria: A version-controlled common requirements document (CRD) is established and maintained.
The CRD is used as the foundational baseline for all software design and development projects.
A formal process for requesting, approving, and documenting customizations or deviations from the CRD for specific countries or systems is in place and followed.

metadata.raw_input: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.

title: CRDM Process for Requirement and Business Process Documentation
statement: The CRDM (Collaborative Requirements Development Methodology) process shall be used to systematically identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and document any business process and its related project-specific requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A formal CRDM process is defined and accessible to all project team members.
Evidence, such as meeting minutes or workshop outputs, demonstrates the use of the CRDM process for identifying and discussing requirements.
All defined business processes and their corresponding requirements are formally documented and have a clear status of agreement (e.g., signed off) in the requirements management system.

metadata.raw_input: Use DescriPtion Use the CRDM Process to CRDM is a generic process and can be used to identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and develoP Project-sPecific document any business process and its related requirements systematically.

title: Local Requirement Analysis and Consensus
statement: The implementation process must include an analysis and consensus-building exercise at the country or project level to adapt and refine generic requirements, even when pre-mapped generic processes exist.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence of a formal review session for requirements at the country or project level is documented.
Documented output (e.g., meeting minutes, updated requirements specification) shows the results of the analysis and any adaptations made.
Sign-off on the localized requirements from relevant country or project level stakeholders is obtained.

metadata.raw_input: Some key processes requirements and requirements were already mapped in this document in a way that should be as generic as possible; but even then, value may be found in the analysis and consensus-building aspect of the exercise itself at a country or project level.

title: Use CRDM Process for Requirement Management
statement: The CRDM (Collaborative Requirements Development Methodology) process must be used to systematically identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and document project-specific business processes and their related requirements. The analysis and consensus-building aspects of the CRDM process should be applied at the country or project level.
acceptance_criteria: A project plan exists that explicitly includes activities and milestones for the CRDM process.
CRDM workshops are conducted with relevant stakeholders for defining project requirements.
Output documents, such as a Business Requirements Document, are created using the CRDM framework and show evidence of stakeholder agreement and sign-off.

metadata.raw_input: Use DescriPtion Use the CRDM Process to CRDM is a generic process and can be used to identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and develoP Project-sPecific document any business process and its related requirements systematically. Some key processes requirements and requirements were already mapped in this document in a way that should be as generic as possible; but even then, value may be found in the analysis and consensus-building aspect of the exercise itself at a country or project level.

title: Requirement and Material Alignment Verification
statement: Materials can be cross-checked against requirements to ensure they align with one another and that all processes are covered by both.
acceptance_criteria: A traceability matrix exists and is maintained, linking requirements to corresponding design specifications and test cases.
A documented process is in place for reviewing and approving the alignment between materials and requirements.
Reports can be generated to demonstrate the coverage status of requirements against all relevant materials.

metadata.raw_input: Materials can be cross-checked against requirements to ensure they align with one another and that all processes are covered by both.

title: Enhance Data Quality and Integrity
statement: The system must implement mechanisms to ensure the accuracy, completeness, consistency, and timeliness of all stored and processed data. This includes preventing, detecting, and correcting data quality issues to ensure patient safety, regulatory compliance, and reliable reporting.
acceptance_criteria: Data must be validated at the point of entry against predefined rules (e.g., date formats, value ranges for lab results, valid diagnosis codes).
The system must provide a mechanism for authorized users to review and correct identified data discrepancies.
The system must generate a data quality dashboard or report showing key metrics such as completeness percentage, error rates, and duplicate record counts.
An audit trail must be maintained for all data corrections, logging the original value, the new value, the user who made the change, and the timestamp.

metadata.raw_input: ImProve dAtA quAlity Issues with data quality are common.

title: Data Lifecycle Mapping and Analysis
statement: An analysis of business processes must be conducted to determine where data enters the system (either directly collected or from another system), how data is processed and analyzed, and how data is shared with users and other systems.
regulation: GDPR - Article 30 - Records of processing activities
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive data flow diagram (DFD) is created, documenting all data ingress, processing, storage, and egress points.
A data lifecycle document is produced that details each stage of data handling, including the actors and systems involved.
The analysis identifies and classifies all data types handled by the system, with special attention to PHI.
The final analysis report and associated diagrams are reviewed and approved by the designated Compliance Officer and System Architect.

metadata.raw_input: An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.

title: Data Quality Lifecycle Analysis
statement: An analysis of business processes shall be conducted to determine where data enters the system (either directly collected or from another system), how data is processed and analyzed, and how data is shared with users and other systems to identify and mitigate data quality issues.
acceptance_criteria: A formal report is produced documenting the analysis of all data entry points.
Data flow diagrams are created, illustrating how data is processed, transformed, and analyzed within the system.
An inventory of all data sharing interfaces with users and external systems is documented.
A log of identified data quality vulnerabilities, ranked by potential impact, is created.
A remediation plan with actionable recommendations for improving data quality is delivered.

metadata.raw_input: ImProve dAtA quAlity Issues with data quality are common. An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.

title: Stakeholder Data Access for Business Processes
statement: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR 164.502 (Uses and disclosures of protected health information)
acceptance_criteria: Given a user with a 'Business Analyst' role, when they access the reporting module, they can generate reports tailored to specific business processes (e.g., patient intake, claims submission).
The generated reports must contain the necessary data fields to allow for the identification and analysis of process-specific issues.
Users must be able to filter and query data within the reports to investigate specific cases or trends.
All access to data through this functionality must be logged in an immutable audit trail, accessible by an 'Administrator' or 'Compliance Officer'.

metadata.raw_input: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.

title: Stakeholder Data Access for Business Processes
statement: The system shall provide authorized stakeholders with the necessary tools and data access to identify, analyze, and resolve specific business process issues and fulfill the data requirements of each process.
acceptance_criteria: Given an authorized stakeholder is logged in, when they navigate to the business process analytics module, then they can view a dashboard of key business processes.

Given the stakeholder is viewing the dashboard, when they select a specific business process (e.g., patient intake, claims submission), then the system displays relevant data and metrics for that process.
Given the stakeholder is viewing process-specific data, when they identify an issue, then they can generate or export a report containing the relevant data for analysis.
Given any action involving PHI, when the action is performed, then the system logs the access in the audit trail in compliance with HIPAA.

metadata.raw_input: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.

title: Resource Usability and Maintenance
statement: The resource should be sustainably maintained, and all documentation/resources must be easily usable (e.g., downloadable, referenceable, and adaptable).
acceptance_criteria: A documented process exists for the periodic review and update of all resources, including version control.
All documentation and resources are available for download in standard, accessible formats (e.g., PDF, DOCX).
Documentation is searchable and includes a table of contents or index to facilitate easy referencing.
Where applicable, resources are provided in a format that allows for adaptation by the user's institution (e.g., templates in DOCX format).

metadata.raw_input: The resource should be sustainably maintained, and all documentation/resources must be easily usable (e.g., downloadable, referenceable, and adaptable).

title: Scalable Information System for National Health Services
statement: The information system must be effective and scalable to support the expansion of national health insurance schemes and provide access to health services for a growing number of citizens.
regulation: ISO/IEC 25010: System and software quality models
ISO/IEC 25023: Measurement of system and software quality - Performance efficiency
acceptance_criteria: The system must support a minimum of 1 million concurrent users with an average response time of less than 2 seconds for key transactions.
The system must demonstrate linear scalability, where adding hardware resources results in a proportional increase in transaction throughput.
The system must be capable of processing at least 10 million insurance claims per 24-hour period.
The system must maintain an uptime of 99.95% during operational hours.
Data storage capacity must be scalable to accommodate a 50% year-over-year growth in data volume without performance degradation.

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems.

title: Feasibility of Common Functional Requirements for National Health Systems
statement: An analysis shall be conducted to determine the feasibility and scope of common functional requirements for a national health insurance system, considering the historical lack of reuse and interoperability between different countries' systems.
acceptance_criteria: A feasibility study report is produced that identifies a core set of common functional requirements.
The report outlines a strategy for handling country-specific variations.
The study is reviewed and approved by the project steering committee.

metadata.raw_input: At the outset, experts questioned if common functional requirements were possible since to date there has been little reuse of national health insurance systems from country to country.

title: Scalable National Health Insurance Information System
statement: The information system must be effective and scalable to support the development and expansion of national health insurance schemes. The system should be designed with common, reusable functional components to facilitate adoption and adaptation across different countries or regions.
acceptance_criteria: The system must demonstrate the capacity to support a 10x increase in user base (citizens, providers) over 5 years with no more than a 15% degradation in key transaction response times (e.g., eligibility check, claim submission).

Core system modules (e.g., enrollment, claims processing, provider management) must be configurable to support at least three different national/regional policy variations without requiring new code development.
End-to-end claim processing time, from submission to adjudication, must be completed within a nationally defined Service Level Agreement (SLA), e.g., 30 days.

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems. At the outset, experts questioned if common functional requirements were possible since to date there has been little reuse of national health insurance systems from country to country.

title: Shared Cross-Country Functional Requirements
statement: The system shall support the common set of functional requirements shared across different countries, as identified through the application of the Clinical Research Data Model (CRDM).
acceptance_criteria: A document exists that defines the common functional requirements identified via the CRDM analysis.
The system architecture and design documents explicitly account for these shared cross-country functional requirements.
System test cases demonstrate that the core shared functionalities are implemented and operate as expected across different country-specific configurations.

metadata.raw_input: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.

title: Cross-Country Functional Requirement Harmonization
statement: The system design must account for the finding that many countries share the same functional requirements, as identified through the application of the CRDM (Clinical Research Data Model).
acceptance_criteria: The system architecture documentation explicitly references the CRDM and the principle of supporting harmonized functional requirements across countries.
A traceability matrix demonstrates that core system features map to shared functional requirements identified for multiple target countries.
System design patterns (e.g., localization, configuration) are used to handle country-specific variations while maintaining a common core for shared functionality.

metadata.raw_input: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.
